articles.title: Meet our team!
articles.contents:
This series of tutorials was produced during a working group hosted by the Living Data Project, led by Jennifer Sunday and Joey Bernhardt in 2022.
The tutorials are based on Canadian open datasets with accompanying R code that can be used to teach/illustrate ecological and evolution concepts and are designed to illustrate and support exploration of a variety of core concepts aimed at undergraduate courses in ecology and evolution.
These are the amazing folks who are working on this project:

Joey Bernhardt



Jenn Sunday



Jory Griffith


Elizabeth Houghton



Margaret A. Slein



Jhoan Chavez


Maxime Fraser Franco
  

Amy Forsythe



Victoria Glynn



Egor Katkov
  


Kirsten Palmier



Zihaohan Sang


Rolando Trejo-Perez


Bryn Wiley



Gracielle Higino
Open Science mentor and consultant, science communicator, specialist in ecology and evolution.

articles.title: Living Data Tutorials
articles.description: Open educational resources from the Living Data Project.
articles.contents: We are a group of early career researchers from Canada creating a series of curated datasets with accompanying R-based tutorials that can be used to teach/illustrate ecological and evolution concepts, based on Canadian-generated data sources.

articles.title: Guidelines for instructors
articles.description: Hosted on this website are 6 teaching tutorials and associated files available for instructors to teach core concepts in  ecology and evolutionary biology. We designed these tutorials to span a variety of topics, skills levels, and formats to allow instructors to use as is or modify according to their needs. Here we outline additional guidelines to help instructors to implement these tutorials in their courses.
articles.contents:
Usage
How should I use these tutorials?
How should I integrate these tutorials into my lesson plan?
How can I modify these to accommodate other skill levels or topics?
Example lesson plan skeleton for a 60 min lesson
10 min overview of topics covered and/or referenced in the tutorial
To make this a longer discussion for a larger course, you could include examples of recent papers drawing important conclusions about the topic at hand based on skills taught in the tutorials
Additional topics and concepts to explore
However, I wonder if it would be valuable to augment the tutorials with questions, activities, or learning objectives that explicitly ask students to consider the benefits and challenges of open datasets, reproducible workflows, and so on as they work through the modules?
